ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about many important thinkers and improved analytical skills

The course was excellent at giving an overview of intellectual history across the Western Hemisphere. 
I learned quite a lot of the most prominent intellectuals of different eras and the general philosophical trends they represented.
a cultural and philosophical inquiry of the history of 19th-20th century intellectuals and their ideas

A broad understanding of the situation of intellectuals throughout modern history, as well as the ability to distinguish how different intellectuals came to be throughout the history of ideas and power. By the end of the course, we gain critical skills that not only aid us in situating the social function of intellectuals, but also understanding of the university as an institution in both the modern and historical sense.
Critical thinking, knowledge of intellectuals across time
Knowledge of mostly 20th century intellectuals; some writing and critical reasoning skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Everything in the course was interesting. Could have more thematic coherence (directly on the theme of the intellectual), as each week seemed to focus primarily on the thought of different thinkers rather than their contributions to the theme of the intellectual.

The course material was fascinating, while not having too many readings so it was perfect in sustaining interest.
The assessment were also fair and interesting to do, standard presentations and essays of a leminar.
The seminar itself though could have been more structured, in that participation was largely based on speaking and being responded to by the professor and organic discussion was minimal. The discussion itself was also unstructured at times, with it depending on professor's questions.

strength: Prof. Renaud's curation of reading assignments and the organization of them by themes--it's so interesting and fruitful to read about the works of prominent intellectuals and had them in conversation with one another through the angles Prof. Renaud presented to us; Prof. Renaud is also one of the BEST history instructors at Yale. He cared a lot about the materials, about teaching and about his students, and I enjoyed and appreciated his input in class discussions--it elevated and deepened the conversations so much. 

weakness: none

Prof. Renaud's teaching style in seminar is very rewarding. His comments and his way of organizing the class not only allow us to develop new ideas in response to other students, but he also provides new sources and readings in response of what people say in class to allow for further learning. People in this class come from across the political spectrum so it was very interesting to hear a wide range of ideas.
The professor was super kind, caring, and committed to students. It was cool that the readings were from a wide range of thinkers. Also loved the open-ended final project.
Good instructor; interesting sources; good balance of work; weakness: quality of class discussion was mixed -- sometimes instructor had to talk a lot to fill the apparent dearth of student engagement

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Most definitely  the material is fascinating and Prof. Renaud is incredible.

I would recommend this course if you are willing to do the readings and don't mind a slightly rigid seminar style.
If you have already taken many historical philosophy classes, you may also find the material less novel and engaging.
ABSOLUTELY! You will learn so much from an instructor who is ready to jump in and guide class discussions and who truly cares about teaching and his students.
Yes, definitely. I emerged out of this course with a much better understanding of what public discourse is, who participates in it, and how it functions today.
Yes, I would. Very interesting material that allows you to reflect on the role of intellectuals.
Yes, especially students interested in history / humanities. Good seminar.
